name: Vikrant Tyagi
position: Senior Director - Strategic Operations, HR, and Program Management at Indian Army | Data Science & Finance Expert
text: The Indian Air Force indeed faces a stark contrast when compared to China's rapid advancements in next-generation air combat platforms, particularly with the introduction of the Shenyang J-35 at the 2024 Zhuhai Air Show.  China is not only producing but also preparing to integrate its second fifth-generation stealth fighter jet, India lags behind in terms of operational fifth-generation fighters and the corresponding advanced carrier capabilities. India‚Äôs journey towards a fifth-generation fighter has been prolonged and, so far, unfruitful.  The indigenous Advanced Medium Combat Aircraft (AMCA) project, which aims to produce India‚Äôs first fifth-generation stealth fighter, is still in the development phase.  Despite optimism surrounding AMCA's prototype and testing timelines, the project remains years away from potentially achieving operational status. In a high-stakes arms race, delays in developing such platforms put the IAF at a critical disadvantage.  The challenge extends beyond airframes. The J-35 is tailored for multirole capabilities similar to the American F-35 variants‚Äîbuilt for air, land, and naval deployment.  China‚Äôs focus on interoperability across air force and navy operations, supported by the EMALS-equipped Fujian carrier, demonstrates a seamless strategy for the future of integrated, networked warfare.  The IAF, in contrast, currently operates no dedicated stealth fighter for potential deployment on India's aircraft carriers. India's carriers, INS Vikrant and INS Vikramaditya, still rely on conventional MiG-29Ks, which lack the stealth features, agility, and network-centric warfare capabilities offered by fifth-generation platforms.  As conflicts become increasingly networked, with stealth, electronic warfare, and data integration at the forefront, India's current fleet, which comprises mostly fourth-generation fighters like the Su-30 MKI and Mirage 2000, struggles to match the evolving threat landscape shaped by China‚Äôs advancements.  The absence of a fifth-generation stealth fighter in the IAF inventory places India in a challenging position when it comes to establishing air dominance or ensuring survival against future-generation adversaries.  In terms of a game-changing platform, the IAF remains in catch-up mode. Even with plans to acquire more advanced Rafale jets and possibly other platforms, the current focus is still on bolstering fourth-generation capabilities rather than shifting towards a truly fifth-generation, multi-role combat solution.

name: Opeyemi Olakitan
text: hashtag #RobotImitationLearning  hashtag #RoboticSurgery (1)  hashtag #Manipulating a needle (2)  hashtag #Lifting body tissue, and (3)  training system utilising imitation learning opens a 'new frontier' in medical robotics. The robot watched surgery videos performed with the skills of a human doctor. robot, trained for the first time by watching videos of seasoned surgeons, executed the same surgical procedures as skillfully as the human doctors. successful use of imitation learning to train surgical robots eliminates the need to program robots with each move required during a medical procedure and brings the field of robotic surgery closer to true autonomy, where robots can perform complex surgeries without human help. findings, led by Johns Hopkins University researchers  ‚úÖThe team, which included Stanford University researchers, used imitation learning to train the da Vinci Surgical System robot to perform three fundamental tasks required in surgical procedures: manipulating a needle, lifting body tissue, and suturing. In each case, the robot trained on the team's model performed the same surgical procedures as skillfully as human doctors. ‚úÖThe model combined imitation learning with the same machine learning architecture that underpins ChatGPT. However, where ChatGPT works with words and text, this model speaks "robot" with kinematics, a language that breaks down the angles of robotic motion into math. ‚úÖThe researchers fed their model hundreds of videos recorded from wrist cameras placed on the arms of da Vinci robots during surgical procedures.  ‚ô¶These videos, recorded by surgeons all over the world, are used for post-operative analysis and then archived. Nearly 7,000 da Vinci robots are used worldwide, and more than 50,000 surgeons are trained on the system, creating a large archive of data for robots to "imitate."  ‚úÖWhat is required is image input and then this AI system finds the right action and this, model can learn the procedure and generalize new environments it hasn't encountered.  ‚úÖThe model could be used to quickly train a robot to perform any type of surgical procedure, the researchers said. The team is now using imitation learning to train a robot to perform not just small surgical tasks but a full surgery.  ‚ùóWhat is new here is they only have to collect imitation learning of different procedures and train a robot to learn it in a couple of days and this enabled acceleration to the goal of autonomy while reducing medical errors and achieving more accurate surgery."  ‚ô¶Attached: Video credit: Johns Hopkins University

text: When we talk about bringing humanoid robots into real homes, we‚Äôre talking about flexibility, reliability, and the ability to handle delicate, real-world tasks.   This clip from one of our recent pilot tests shows a simple task, but one that reveals the complex coordination behind every movement.  ‚ñ∂Ô∏é Redesigned from the ground up, Robody‚Äôs new arm combines robust robotic arms with a soft shell, giving it the dexterity needed for tasks like opening drawers and handling items, and the softness making sure nothing gets damaged.  ‚ñ∂Ô∏é Exploring the use of simple grippers, we find they work great for items of different shapes, sizes, and textures ‚Äî as shown here, they handle the many little challenges of everyday tasks well. But also, more often than not, we miss having a full hand, so stay tuned.  Our goal? To make Robody as adaptable as possible, allowing caregivers to handle the countless variations they‚Äôll encounter in real homes. text: The nuclear triad describes the capability of a military to deliver nuclear warheads via bombers, in missile silos on land and submarines. Nuclear missiles based on land are often classified as Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs). Submarines may carry Submarine-Launched Ballistic Missiles (SLBMs) armed with nuclear warheads. text: At AirShow China 2024, Russia showcased the Su-57E, the export version of its cutting-edge Su-57 5th-generation stealth fighter. Specifically designed for international markets, the Su-57E offers advanced capabilities to buyers seeking a top-tier multifunctional fighter. The aircraft combines stealth, high maneuverability, and formidable firepower, catering to various combat missions in modern conflict zones.  With a maximum take-off weight of 34,000 kg, the Su-57E is classified as a heavy fighter, optimized for a range of air-to-air, ground, and sea operations. Its stealth features, including reduced radar, infrared, and visual signatures, allow it to penetrate defended areas and engage targets with minimal detection, making it a powerful tool for offensive and intelligence-gathering missions in contested environments.  The Su-57E is powered by two engines, each delivering 14,500 kg of thrust, enabling it to reach a maximum speed of 1,350 km/h near ground level and a flight range of up to 7,800 km with in-flight refueling. This combination of speed and range allows the Su-57E to undertake extended missions and respond rapidly to threats. The aircraft is highly maneuverable, thanks to advanced thrust-vectoring technology that enables complex aerial maneuvers crucial for close air combat and evasion. Its supermaneuverability and ability to cruise at supersonic speeds without afterburners provide tactical flexibility, allowing it to approach distant targets efficiently and evade enemy defenses at lower altitudes.  The Su-57E also stands out for its extensive and versatile weapons-carrying capabilities, equipped with 12 hardpoints, including six internal fuselage hardpoints that preserve its stealth profile. This configuration allows it to carry a diverse combat load, including air-to-air missiles, bombs, and advanced precision-guided munitions. The Su-57E can be armed with Russia's high-precision "Long Arm" weapons, enabling long-range engagement against air and ground targets. Its multichannel weapon control system is adaptable to various mission profiles, facilitating smooth transitions between different engagement scenarios and enhancing its role as a true multirole fighter.

name: Actuators MDPI
text: hashtag #Article  üìú Octopus-Inspired Robotic Arm Powered by Shape Memory Alloys (SMA) by Shubham Deshpande and Yara Almubarak, PhD üîó  ;    Traditional rigid grippers that are used for underwater systems lack flexibility and have lower degrees of freedom. These systems might damage the underwater environment while conducting data acquisition and data sampling. Soft robotics, which is mainly focused on creating robots with extremely soft materials are more delicate for the grasping of objects underwater. These systems tend to damage the underwater ecosystem in the least possible way. In this paper, we have presented a simplified design of a soft arm inspired by the octopus arm actuated by coiled Shape Memory Alloys (SMAs) using completely flexible lightweight material. The characterization arm performance under various load and input current conditions is shown. We hope this work will serve as a basis for the future of underwater grasping utilizing soft robotics.

name: Daniel Christadoss
text: The Makeblock Mega is one of the few COTS mobile robots I have bought. I just pulled it out of mothballs and thought will play with it.  It has an Arduino Mega clone in it. It can be programmed with the Arduino IDE as well as Scratch. And since PictoBlox can do the Mega we may have a chance there. You can also pick up quite a few Arduino examples. It has solderable connections in case you want to piggyback a Rpi on it. It has canned examples for Line Follow etc. Of course it is build like a tank and you can probably add on an armed robot of your own creation. Nowadays we need to use the 18650 Lipo's and it has a pack for that. I am sure the brave can also ROS it and even mount a Lidar on top. Or use a 3D camera. I think it has Bluetooth too. The meccanum wheels look like fun and I am wonderfing how maze solving would look on it. Let's us try that as well. Maybe ToF sensors on all sides. I know I always advocate building one from scratch, but for those who are busy and yet want to experiment this is a nice platform.

name: Curry Khoo
text: AMD and Intel are using x86 architecture, meanwhile Apple, Qualcomm, Samsung are using ARM architecture for their Chip.   Here its history and different between these two architecture.  It took Apple decades of R&D & heavy investment on ARM for them to deliver one of the best Chip in the market, the M series which powering the Mac series and also topline latest iPad.  Recently Qualcomm launch X Elite series, an ARM processor for Windows PC/ Laptop!  PC & Desktop market used to be dominated by x86 only, either Intel or AMD. But today, we see huge change & shift towards ARM, as its getting more powerful and energy efficient.  One of the pushing factor are ARM fabrication partner, TSMC and Samsung. Which allowed company like Apple and Qualcomm to focus on the Design and no need worry bout manufacturing the Chip.  We will more company that focus on Design, even in Malaysia which we already have Oppstar and SkypeChip. Keeping my eye on this area.

name: Richard Johnson
text: https://lnkd.in/epbpYVaf The article "Ma Deuce ‚Äî The M2 .50-Caliber Machine Gun" from The Armory Life delves into the historical development and enduring legacy of the M2 .50-caliber machine gun. Initially conceptualized during World War I, the formidable machine gun addressed the challenge posed by German observation balloons and aircraft, which were shielded from standard small arms fire. The call to create a powerful weapon came from American General John J. "Black Jack" Pershing, leading to collaboration with John Moses Browning, a legendary firearms designer. By adopting elements from the German Mauser Tankgewehr M1918 anti-tank rifle and enhancing specifications, the M2 machine gun emerged as an influential tool with a high muzzle velocity, evolving into a versatile weapon platform.  The M2 .50-caliber machine gun, commonly referred to as "Ma Deuce," became integral to US military operations across different branches and roles. Its adaptability allowed for incorporation into tanks, naval vessels, aircraft, and numerous ground platforms. The M2HB variant, a result of posthumous modifications to Browning‚Äôs design, honored the prototype's strengths through durability, long-range effectiveness, and unmatched stopping power against a myriad of targets, including vehicles and fortified positions. Despite various attempts over the decades to innovate beyond Browning's original design, the M2's indisputable efficacy ensured its continued use worldwide.  The article further discusses the ammunition types and operational nuances of the M2, such as its feeding mechanisms, firing modes, and the absence of a manual safety, requiring field improvisations for security. The adoption of the M2A1 model introduced enhancements like a quick-change barrel system and fixes to headspace and timing issues, reflecting modern advancements while preserving the timeless robustness of the weapon. Now, over a century since its inception, the M2 continues to hold primacy in American military arsenals, validating its status as a remarkably enduring fixture in both historical and contemporary military conflict.

text: Morocco is set to integrate Turkish Bayraktar Akinci combat drones into its arsenal in February 2025, as reported by Le Desk on November 11, 2024. This acquisition is part of Morocco's effort to modernize its military capabilities. Produced by the Turkish company Baykar, these high-tech drones will join the Moroccan fleet, which currently includes 19 Bayraktar TB2 drones acquired in 2021.  With this new addition, Morocco is making a significant leap forward in technological and operational capacities, strengthening its Royal Moroccan Air Force (FRA) within the Royal Armed Forces (FAR) to respond effectively to regional security challenges. The Akinci distinguishes itself from its predecessor, the TB2, with advanced features and increased payload capacity, allowing it to carry a variety of munitions, including precision-guided missiles.  The Akinci boasts a wingspan of 20 meters and a maximum payload capacity of 1,500 kg. It is equipped with cutting-edge technologies such as an AESA radar and satellite communication systems, providing a flight endurance of 25 hours and a range of up to 7,500 km. These characteristics make it an asset for long-range operations in challenging areas, offering Morocco broad coverage and targeted strike capabilities.  Outfitted for complex missions, the Akinci features a range of armament options, including air-to-ground ballistic TRG-230 Kaplan missiles, SOM cruise missiles, and Tolun bombs. Notably, it is the first drone capable of launching an air-launched cruise missile (ALCM), a technological advance that significantly enhances Morocco's defense capabilities. Additional available munitions include the laser-guided Cirit missile, the long-range anti-tank missile L-UMTAS, Bozok munitions, and various air-to-air missiles, developed in collaboration with T√ºrkiye's Scientific and Technological Research Council (T√ºbitak Sage).

text: Torobo, a Japanese humanoid robot, has reached new heights in autonomous cleaning thanks to a powerful learning method known as Deep Predictive Learning (DPL).  just released a new demo of its flagship humanoid smoothly wiping a table on its own, guided by technology created at‚Äôs Ogata Lab. The method enables Torobo to predict and adjust its movements in real time, bridging the gap betwen simple robot motions and complex, natural human actions.  As the robot moves, blue dots mark its current focus points, while red dots highlight the next movements it plans to make. This predictive approach allows Torobo to maintain smooth, coordinated wiping actions, applying just the right amount of pressure for effective cleaning. It learned this skill by watching human operators control it remotely, recording each demonstration‚Äôs joint angles, visual feedback, and pressure data.  After observing and recording these teleoperated sessions dozens of times, Torobo applied what it learned to replicate the motions autonomously. Built for industrial work alongside humans, Torobo has arms with seven joints that enable it to move in human-like ways.  Tokyo Robotics has recently showcased other demonstrations of Torobo using its versatile arms to saw wood and accurately hammer nails.  Tokyo Robotics plans to launch a new version of Torobo in Japan by March 2025, with an international release slated for October.

text: * hashtag #India to Boost Air Defense with  hashtag #Russian Pantsir Missile-Gun System*  India has taken a major step to enhance its air defense by partnering with Russia to acquire the advanced Pantsir air defense missile-gun system. Bharat Dynamics Limited ( ) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Russian arms exporter Rosoboronexport ( ) for this acquisition.  The Pantsir system, similar to Israel's , is a sophisticated mobile defense setup designed to counter aerial threats like drones, missiles, and enemy aircraft, particularly around military bases. It is equipped with short- and medium-range missiles, as well as dual 30mm automatic cannons, providing multi-layered defense. Additionally, its advanced radar and electro-optical tracking systems enable it to detect and intercept targets up to 36 kilometers away and at altitudes of up to 15 kilometers.  This partnership marks a significant upgrade for India‚Äôs air defense infrastructure and strengthens its strategic capabilities.

name: Jan Zizka
position: Founder and CEO @ Brightpick | Founder @ Photoneo | AI robots for fully automated order fulfillmentü§ñ
text: Many people ask why Brightpick Autopicker picks by moving its totes up & down instead of the robotic arm.  The answer is simple: we already have motors in place to move the totes when the robot retrieves them from the shelves.  Sure, using the robotic arm to pick might look cooler, but it would require an additional motor, increasing both cost and complexity.  Instead, we leverage the same motor that lifts the totes during retrieval for the picking process. And with regenerative braking, the additional energy usage is minimal.  The most efficient solutions aren‚Äôt always the flashiest; sometimes, a bit of creativity leads to smarter, simpler outcomes.

name: Rauf ur Rahim
position: Machine Learning | Data Sciences | R&D | AI Product Development @ Agile, MLOps, UI/UX, PMP
text: The AI Machine Gun of the Future Is Already Here  Amid a rising tide of low-cost weaponized adversary drones menacing American troops abroad, the US military is pulling out all the stops to protect its forces from the ever-present threat of death from above. But between expensive munitions, futuristic but complicated directed energy weapons, and its own growing drone arsenal, the Pentagon is increasingly eyeing an elegantly simple solution to its growing drone problem: reinventing the gun. At the Technology Readiness Experimentation (T-REX) event in August, the US Defense Department tested an artificial intelligence-enabled autonomous robotic gun system developed by fledgling defense contractor Allen Control Systems dubbed the "Bullfrog." Consisting of a 7.62-mm M240 machine gun mounted on a specially designed rotating turret outfitted with an electro-optical sensor, proprietary AI, and computer vision software, the Bullfrog was designed to deliver small arms fire on drone targets with far more precision than the average US service member can achieve with a standard-issue weapon like the M4 carbine or next-generation XM7 rifle. Indeed, footage of the Bullfrog in action published by ACS shows the truck-mounted system locking onto small drones and knocking them out of the sky with just a few shots.

name: Exponential Growth Strategy
text: How Did the $32 Billion ARM Company Emerge from a Small Town? The Power of Exponential Growth Strategy.  üéØOur founder's Vision and thoughts are full of insightful reflections.  üéØARM Company, now a $32 billion giant, started as a small technology group in the charming university town of Cambridge, England‚Äîhome to just 150,000 people. Yet, this seemingly modest origin story proves the immense potential of a well-executed exponential growth strategy.  üéØThe rise of ARM holds valuable lessons for companies everywhere, sparking the question: Could such success emerge from our country, Turkey?  üéØARM‚Äôs journey began with a groundbreaking invention: the Acorn RISC Machine (ARM) processor, a low-power, highly efficient microprocessor.  üéØReleased in 1985, it quickly became a favorite for its remarkable energy efficiency.  üéØThis innovation laid the foundation for ARM Holdings in 1990, a company that revolutionized the tech industry with its licensing business model.  üéØInstead of manufacturing chips, ARM allowed other companies to use its processor designs.  üéØThis ingenious approach exploded its reach‚Äîtech companies worldwide could create their own chips based on ARM‚Äôs designs, driving rapid, exponential growth.  üéØPartnerships with industry giants like Apple and VLSI Technology solidified ARM‚Äôs dominance, especially in mobile devices. Its flexible, energy-efficient designs became the foundation for billions of devices, from smartphones to IoT devices.  üéØIn 2016, ARM‚Äôs success caught the attention of SoftBank, which acquired the company for an astounding $32 billion, recognizing its crucial role in the future of IoT, AI, and mobile technologies.  üéØARM‚Äôs Exponential Growth is a powerful example of how strategic partnerships, innovation, and a scalable business model can propel a company from humble beginnings to global dominance.  üéØThe story of ARM shows that with the right strategy, even small origins can lead to extraordinary results.  üéØCould your company replicate this success? How do you implement Exponential Growth Strategy in your company and in your life?  üéØThe future holds infinite possibilities‚Äîif we harness the power of Exponential Growth.  üéØTogether, let‚Äôs celebrate those who dare to dream and strive to change the world!  üéØAlways trust yourself, Believe in you , Move on with Love, Courage and Faith . ‚úî  Follow ‚Ü™for more, to be interaction with our activities, for motivation and inspiration .  ?

name: Bertalan Mesk√≥, MD, PhD
position: Director of The Medical Futurist Institute (Keynote Speaker, Researcher, Author & Futurist)
text: This video caused quite the stir in the surgical community.  Researchers used a method called "imitation learning" to train the da Vinci Surgical System robot to perform three fundamental tasks required in surgical procedures: manipulating a needle, lifting body tissue, and suturing.  During imitation learning, the model uses kinematics, a language that breaks down the angles of robotic motion into math, similarly to how ChatGPT works with words and text.  It seems the robot could perform the procedures as skillfully as human doctors.  "The researchers fed their model hundreds of videos recorded from wrist cameras placed on the arms of da Vinci robots during surgical procedures. These videos, recorded by surgeons all over the world, are used for post-operative analysis and then archived. Nearly 7,000 da Vinci robots are used worldwide, and more than 50,000 surgeons are trained on the system, creating a large archive of data for robots to "imitate."  They are now using the same method to train a robot to perform not just surgical tasks but a full surgery.  What do surgeons think about its potential?

name: David N.
text: The IRON humanoid robot, developed by XPENG, represents a significant advancement in robotics, particularly in its design and functionality. Here‚Äôs a comprehensive list of its features: Key Features Joint and Movement Capabilities: The IRON robot boasts over 60 joints and 200 degrees of freedom, allowing it to perform a wide range of human-like movements, including standing, sitting, and lying down 1 . Its hands are designed with 15 degrees of freedom, providing it with the ability to grasp and manipulate objects with precision and tactile feedback 1 . AI and Machine Learning Integration: The robot is equipped with advanced AI and machine learning technologies, enabling it to learn from its environment and improve its interactions over time 2 . Human Interaction: Designed to imitate human expressions and interactions, the IRON robot can engage with people in a more relatable manner, enhancing its usability in various settings. Functional Design: The humanoid structure includes a torso, head, arms, and legs, making it suitable for interacting with human tools and environments 3 . Industrial Applications: Initially deployed in EV factories, the IRON robot is intended to assist in manufacturing tasks, showcasing its practical applications in industrial settings. Advanced Sensory Systems: The robot is likely equipped with cameras and sensors that enhance its ability to perceive and navigate its surroundings, although specific details on these systems were not highlighted in the sources. Versatile Functionality: The design allows for various functional purposes, from operational tasks in factories to potential roles in customer service or healthcare environments.

name: Laura H.
position: Retired Arizona Junior Science and Humanities Director turned world explorer, storyteller, and global recipe enthusiast. Passionate advocate for K-12 education and raising awareness about dense breast cancer risks.
text: Silk Escape Maps   During World War II, silk escape maps became an ingenious lifeline for many in the armed forces. Unlike traditional maps, these silk versions could be tucked away with remarkable ease, folded into the smallest of spaces, and remained completely silent when handled‚Äî‚Äî a crucial detail for anyone trying to stay undetected. For pilots and soldiers facing the risk of being shot down or captured behind enemy lines, these maps offered a discreet, durable tool to navigate their way to safety. They were printed with intricate details, showing escape routes, geographical features, and key landmarks that could guide them through hostile terrain toward friendly territory.  After the war, these silk maps took on a new life in a way that seems both sweetly poetic and practical. Silk was still a precious material, and people, eager to make use of every resource, began transforming the maps into garments. Soldiers‚Äô survival tools became scarves, handkerchiefs, and even dresses‚Äîa quiet nod to the strength of those who had once carried them. Each piece was not just clothing but a symbol of resilience, a reminder of a wartime relic now worn in peace. Today, these silk maps are treasured collector‚Äôs items, holding memories of ingenuity, survival, and transformation‚Äîsilent witnesses to the journey from conflict to a new beginning.  Pictured are examples of a 1940 World War II British Army escape map turned into a scarf and a rare surviving robe.

text: hashtag #China Shows its upgraded version of the  hashtag #Israeli Anti-Tank Missile " hashtag #Spike". The Chinese-made M-321 " hashtag #Saber" multipurpose missile weighs 28 kg and has a diameter of 148 mm. It is therefore larger in diameter than the missile, which is only 127 mm. In addition, its diameter is also larger than the -12. The M-321 "Saber" is very similar to the Israeli "Spike" missile. It comes in four models with different ranges, short-range, medium-range, long-range and ultra-long-range, with ranges from 300 meters to 4,500 meters, the ultra-long-range model is 25 kilometers. The "Saber" adopts confidential data link + inertial guidance + uncooled infrared thermal imaging terminal guidance. It has automatic image guidance capabilities and can automatically destroy the target through the infrared image captured by the seeker. It is equivalent to realizing the entire self-guiding process through a photo. Images and information instructions can also be transmitted via wireless data links. The launcher uses real-time images to determine the target, correct the missile's flight path, and ultimately destroy the target with precision. It can be used anywhere (on land, water, and in the air)to attack tanks and armored vehicles, carry out fortified operations, and even attack targets such as low-flying armed helicopters. M-321 "Saber" was exported from to 7 years ago, which introduced it in 2017. Its anti-tank combat capability has significantly surpassed that of , forcing India to import the "Saber" from .

text: Here is a low-budget telerobotic arm that I built myself. It is a computer vision-based robotic arm control system capable of being operated remotely from anywhere in the world. Using OpenCV and MediaPipe for hand tracking, the system transmits distance data to an MQTT broker over the internet, enabling the robotic arm to respond to detected hand movements.

name: Daniel Christadoss
text: My project pipeline wishlist.  There was a time when I used to buy off the shelf robots. I did check out the Viam  It is a unique robotic service. I bought the lidar to retrofit the iCreate robot. I think the time has come to wet my ROS palate. I have flirted with ROS on and off and it does have its merits. The Viam is an excellent platform to have the lidar mounted on it. The Viam is originally designed for a Raspberry pi and I do have some of those lying around. We could even add an armed robot to the Viam. By the way the Viam also has an integrated camera. Or maybe we could actually use the Viam service instead of ROS I am sure Viam will love that. Let me have your ideas. What would you do if you had these to play with? I will try and incorporate if practical. I know the hacker spirit in you will come up with some out of the world ideas.

name: Guido Appenzeller
position: Investing in Infra & AI at a16z. Previously CTO @ Intel & VMware, CEO @ Big Switch, 2x Founder.
text: Cool paper from Moo Jin Kim et al. how to control a robot arm using natural language. What's impressive is that the model is small (based on Llama 2 7b) and runs on a consumer graphics card.  The basic idea is you specify a high level task in language (e.g. "Put the Coke next to Taylor Swift") and that's enough to drive the robot arm. The model is based on Llama 2 7b plus a Vision transformer. Image and instructions are encoded as input tokens and the output tokens are decoded into actions of the robot arm. It can be adapted to different robot arm hardware.  As the model is small and based on an open source model, it cheaper to train and it runs on an RTX 4090 consumer graphics card at 6 updates/s. This makes this a lot more practical than some of the much larger models.  Project site: Paper on arXiv:  Congrats to the team from/and Toyota.

text: Airbus A321MPA Selected as French Navy's Next-Generation Long-Range Maritime Patrol Aircraft. In a strategic win for Airbus Defence and Space, the French Ministry of the Armed Forces has chosen theA321MPA (Maritime Patrol Aircraft) proposal for its Patmar program, replacing‚Äôs competing bid. The French financial journal reported this decision "La Tribune" on November 7, 2024, marking a significant step in the French Navy's plans to modernise its maritime patrol capabilities post-2030. Based on the A321XLR airframe, the A321MPA is set to replace France‚Äôs aging fleet of Atlantique 2 aircraft, which have been operational since the 1990s, conducting missions such as anti-submarine warfare (ASW), anti-surface warfare, and intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR). The wings for the aircraft are produced at thefacility at Broughton in north Wales.

name: Arunachalam Kumar
position: Head Operations | Electrical and Electronics Engineering
text: The MQ-9 Reaper is a highly capable, remotely piloted unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) developed by General Atomics Aeronautical Systems for the U.S. Air Force. Known for its versatility in both surveillance and combat roles, the MQ-9 is widely used in military operations worldwide.  Key Features and Specifications  1. High Altitude, Long Endurance: The MQ-9 Reaper operates at altitudes up to 50,000 feet and has an endurance of approximately 27 hours, allowing it to conduct extended surveillance and combat missions over vast areas. 2. Heavy Payload Capacity: The Reaper is equipped with a variety of payloads, including precision-guided munitions like Hellfire missiles, GBU-12 Paveway II laser-guided bombs, and GBU-38 Joint Direct Attack Munitions (JDAM). It can carry up to 3,800 pounds of weaponry, making it one of the most heavily armed UAVs in service. 3. Advanced Surveillance Capabilities: The MQ-9 features a sophisticated suite of sensors, including a multi-spectral targeting system (MTS) that combines infrared, electro-optical, and laser designation capabilities. This system allows the Reaper to gather detailed intelligence, support surveillance missions, and identify targets for precision strikes. 4. Real-Time Data Transmission: Equipped with high-bandwidth data links, the MQ-9 can transmit real-time video and telemetry data to command centers worldwide. This allows for coordinated missions, target verification, and on-the-ground support in real time. 5. Autonomous Flight and Targeting: While typically controlled by human operators, the MQ-9 has autonomous capabilities for takeoff, landing, and mission navigation. Its automated flight and targeting functions reduce pilot workload and enable precise strikes with minimal collateral damage.  Operational Use  The MQ-9 Reaper has been instrumental in counter-terrorism efforts, providing both ISR (intelligence, surveillance, reconnaissance) and strike capabilities in high-risk areas. Its ability to loiter over targets, gather data, and execute precision attacks has made it a valuable asset in U.S. military operations in the Middle East, Africa, and other regions.  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢  ‚Ä¢

This is not the first time humans have tried to build a robot to play table tennis; it's amazing to see how far technology has come over the years.  1980s: The first robot to play table tennis was developed in Japan. It was a simple robot that could hit the ball back and forth but didn't have much complexity.  2000s: German researchers developed a robot arm that used a combination of cameras and sensors to track the ball and react.  2011: A Japanese company developed a robot called "Forpheus" that utilized advanced sensors and AI to predict the ball's trajectory.  2014: The Chinese company, Tencent, developed a robot called "TT-100" that used ML algorithms to improve its skills.  Back to DeepMind's robot, which made its debut against 29 human opponents - from beginners to advanced players - and delivered an impressive mid-range performance. A solid score that showcases its skills!  Why always table tennis?  Maybe because this sport offers the perfect blend of complexity and control, testing the robot's quick reflexes, precise movements, and strategic thinking in a safe and predictable environment.  Also, DeepMind's robot is notable for its AI-powered ability to learn and adapt quickly, allowing it to improve its skills and take on new opponents! name: Richard Smith
text: Taiwan seeks $2 billion arms sale from US, Raytheon  Rich Smith November 09, 2024     The Defense Security Cooperation Agency notified Congress in late October that Taiwan intends to purchase AN/TPS-77 and AN/TPS-78 ground-based radar systems for medium to long range air surveillance. Additionally, the Taiwanese intend to purchase National Advanced Surface-to-Air Missile Systems (NASAMS) and related equipment.  Lockheed Martin (NYSE: LMT) makes the AN/TPS-77 and Northrop Grumman (NYSE: NOC) makes the AN/TPS-78, however, Taiwan will be buying these systems second-hand from U.S. Air Force stockpiles, for an estimated cost of $828 million.  As regards, the NASAMS, Taiwan will purchase three complete medium-range air defense systems, with included AN/MPQ-64F1 Sentinel radar systems and a total of123 Advanced Medium-Range Air-to-Air Missiles-Extended Range (AMRAAM-ER) to fire from them.  RTX Corporation (NYSE: RTX) is named principal contractor on the latter sale, which will be worth $1.16 billion if approved by Congress.  The total value of the two arms deals thus amounts to just under $2 billion in value.

name: Nicanor Cheruiyot
position: Experienced EOD/IEDD/EHAT/EORE /AASC Instructor | 14 Years in Military Training | Expert in Explosive Threat Mitigation | Pursuing BA in Peace Studies
text: Evolution of IED Tactical Characterization in Somalia  The use of IEDs by AS, has evolved significantly over the years. This evolution reflects changes in tactics, technology, and countermeasures.  Early Stages (2006-2010) Basic IEDs: Initially, IEDs were relatively simple, often using readily available materials like ANFO. These devices were typically command-detonated using basic electronic circuits. Roadside Bombs: The primary tactic involved placing IEDs along roadsides to target military convoys and supply routes.  Mid-Evolution (2011-2015) Increased Sophistication: AS began incorporating more sophisticated components, such as military-grade explosives and advanced triggering mechanisms, including pressure plates and remote-controlled devices. Diversification of Tactics: The group diversified its tactics, employing VBIEDs and PBIEDs to target high-profile locations and individuals. International Influence: There was a notable influence from international terrorist organizations, particularly AQAP, which provided technical expertise and advanced components. Recent Developments (2016-Present) Technological Advancements: The use of more advanced technology, such as mobile phones and radio-controlled triggers, has increased the effectiveness and lethality of IEDs. Complex Attacks: AS has executed complex attacks involving multiple IEDs and coordinated assaults, such as the 2017 Mogadishu truck bombing. Adaptation to Countermeasures: The group has adapted to C-IED measures by developing low-metal content IEDs to evade detection and using decoy devices to confuse and overwhelm security forces.  Detection Techniques and Equipment EDD: EDD teams have been crucial in detecting IEDs, especially in high-risk areas like airports and military bases. Advanced Sensors: The use of GPR and other advanced sensors has improved the detection of buried IEDs.  MVCP: These are deployed to inspect vehicles for hidden IEDs, using a combination of manual searches and advanced scanning equipment.  Training and Capacity Building Comprehensive Training Programs: AMISOM and Somali forces have undergone extensive training in IED detection, disposal, and post-blast investigation. These programs are often supported by international partners like UNMAS and the UKMST. Continuous Re-evaluation: Due to the evolving nature of IED threats, there is a constant re-evaluation of personnel skills and updating them on new trends to ensure they can operate efficiently and deliver on their mission mandate.  Conclusion The evolution of IED tactics in Somalia reflects a continuous arms race between militant groups and C-IED forces. While AS has developed increasingly sophisticated devices and tactics, international and local forces have responded with advanced detection techniques, equipment, and comprehensive training programs. This ongoing battle underscores the need for constant vigilance, adaptation, and innovation in C-IED efforts.

name: Rommel Gavieta
position: Infra & Digital Connectivity Adviser at Philippine Reclamation Authority
text: Credit to Thomas Newdick Oct 17, 2024  Army Confirms It‚Äôs Exploring Requirements For A New Heavy-Lift Helicopter To Replace Chinook    A CH-47 Chinook replacement remains a major unknown when it comes to the U.S. Army's Future Vertical Lift vision.  The U.S. Army is actively exploring options for a new-generation heavy-lift rotorcraft to replace the CH-47 Chinook. Although plans are still very much in their infancy, they have broader implications for future heavy-lift capabilities, especially for the Pacific theater.  Confirmation that work on a Chinook successor is ongoing comes as the service progresses with its Future Long-Range Assault Aircraft (FLRAA) tiltrotor, which will replace part of the UH-60 Black Hawk fleet, and after its cancelation of the Future Attack Reconnaissance Aircraft (FARA), which would have partially replaced the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior armed scout helicopter, now retired without any plans for a direct successor.  In response to a question from TWZ, Brig. Gen. Cain Baker, the director of the Future Vertical Lift Cross-Functional Team, or FVL CFT, at Army Futures Command, provided an update on Chinook replacement plans at the Association of the U.S. Army‚Äôs annual symposium yesterday. Within the Army, this is known as Capability Set, or ‚ÄúCape Set,‚Äù Four, part of the wider Future Vertical Lift (FVL) effort. FLRAA and FARA were responses to other FVL Capability Sets. Cap Set 4 also evolved in part from earlier efforts, including the Joint Heavy Lift (JHL) and Joint Multi-Role (JMR) programs.  In the meantime, the Army‚Äôs Chinook fleet ‚Äî which numbers more than 470 aircraft ‚Äî will soldier on as the service‚Äôs heavy-lift rotorcraft for many more years to come. This could be aided by the latest Chinook Block II upgrade program. This includes new rotor blades, a revised fuel tank configuration, and other improvements, while there is also a separate option to add more powerful General Electric T408 engines.  While the structural and performance enhancements introduced in the Chinook Block II program add speed and lift to an airframe design that‚Äôs now over 60 years old, the helicopter offers nothing close to FLRAA levels of performance. At the same time, Chinook Block II has always been seen as a stopgap until a replacement platform can be defined, a conundrum Cape Set Four is now grappling with.  Other than the Chinook, the only other suitable heavy-lift rotorcraft currently in production is the CH-53K King Stallion, as operated by the U.S. Marine Corps.  Along with concerns over rotorcraft survivability is the interest expressed by the Army (as well as the Marine Corps and Air Force) in distributed logistics chains, leveraging, at least in part, increasingly large uncrewed aerial cargo platforms. This could also raise questions about whether a new heavy-lift platform is necessary or cost-effective.

text: üåê The J-15D: A Leap Forward in China's Naval Electronic Warfare üåê  China's arms industry continues to push boundaries, unveiling innovative and formidable weapon systems. The spotlight now shines on the J-15D EW, the latest iteration of its carrier-based fighter, showcased at the Zhuhai Air Show. This evolution of the 4.5-generation J-15 marks a significant boost in China‚Äôs electronic warfare and SEAD (Suppression of Enemy Air Defenses) capabilities.  üöÄ Key Highlights of the J-15D:  Electronic Warfare Expertise: A specialized variant of the J-15, the J-15D is tailored for electronic attack, equipped to jam and suppress enemy radar and communications from a standoff distance.  Design and Features: Retaining the robust airframe of the Su-33, the J-15D incorporates specialized electronic pods and antennas, omitting the standard internal cannon to make room for advanced EW systems.  Two-Seater Configuration: The second operator focuses on managing complex EW systems, a necessity for real-time battlefield responses. Advanced Systems: Outfitted with multi-function displays (MFDs) and tailored avionics for threat analysis and response strategies.  Carrier-Based Operations: Reinforced for short-deck landings, compatible with China's Liaoning and Shandong aircraft carriers, expanding operational reach and tactical flexibility.  üîß Strategic Advantages: The J-15D‚Äôs ability to disrupt enemy defenses ensures a safer environment for broader strike groups. Its offensive and defensive jamming capabilities add a critical layer of protection and operational depth for China‚Äôs carrier strike formations.  üí¨ The unveiling of the J-15D positions China‚Äôs navy at the forefront of modern electronic warfare, echoing capabilities found in systems like the U.S. EA-18G Growler. This new asset reinforces China's goal of projecting power and protecting its fleets in contested regions.  üëâ What are your thoughts on this advancement in electronic warfare?

name: mohammed yousuf
text: Xpeng's Iron Robot: A New Era of Robotics Imagine a world where robots, not humans, assemble cars. That‚Äôs the future Xpeng, a Chinese electric car company, is working towards. They‚Äôve unveiled their latest creation, a humanoid robot named Iron. Iron, the Robotic Assistant Iron is more than just a machine; it‚Äôs a highly advanced robot designed to assist humans in various tasks. It's like a real-life Iron Man, but without the superhero suit. How Does Iron Work? * Super-Smart Brain: Iron is powered by a super-smart AI chip called Turing. This chip allows Iron to think, learn, and make decisions, just like a human brain. * Flexible Body: With over 60 joints, Iron is incredibly flexible. It can move its arms, legs, and fingers with precision, making it capable of performing complex tasks. * Real-World Applications: Currently, Iron is being used in Xpeng's factories to assemble cars. It can handle delicate parts and work tirelessly, making the production process more efficient. The Future of Robotics Xpeng's vision for Iron extends beyond factory floors. In the future, these robots could be used as personal assistants, helping with household chores or providing companionship. They could even work in dangerous environments, such as disaster zones. A Step Towards the Future Xpeng's Iron robot is a significant step towards a future where humans and robots work together harmoniously. It's a testament to the rapid advancements in AI and robotics, and it's exciting to see what the future holds.

text: üî¥Minuteman III test showcases readiness of US nuclear force's safe, effective deterrent   In this test, the missile's reentry vehicles traveled some 4,200 miles (6,760 km) before impacting their targets at the Reagan Test site in the remote Kwajalein Atoll.  The Minuteman III missiles that form a critical leg of the U.S. nuclear triad each carry one nuclear-armed reentry vehicle.  This test launch is part of routine and periodic activities intended to demonstrate that the United States‚Äô nuclear deterrent is safe, secure, reliable and effective to deter 21st century threats and reassure our allies. Such tests have occurred over 300 times before, and this test is not the result of current world events-- US claims!!!

name: Calian Defence Solutions
text: Airborne Electromagnetic Warfare is Critical for NATO‚Äôs Airpower Edge - Royal United Services Institute  "Airborne EW capabilities play several key roles in high-intensity air operations, and are especially important for the vital suppression and destruction of enemy air defences (SEAD/DEAD) mission set. The first role is defensive electronic countermeasures (ECM), where aircraft employ directed jamming effects to try to degrade and break the lock of either the radar of a hostile aircraft or surface-to-air missile system that is targeting them. The second role is offensive stand-off escort jamming, where specialised aircraft with high-powered jamming arrays either mounted in the airframe or in underwing pods degrade hostile airborne and ground-based radar threats from much further back."  Military training scenarios need to reflect complex and dynamic real-world situations. Atwe integrate the latest lessons learned into military training scenarios to deliver the most realistic experience possible for the combined-arms team. This means training for contested air space, ISR and targeting processes, and responding to successful cyber attacks. For more information on how we design, develop and deliver realistic and challenging training, see our white paper on integrating lessons learned into training: @  For more, please visit ourHub @and Calian-Advanced Technologies @   Note: Articles posted or shared on thissite are for informational purposes only. Any views or opinions expressed herein are those of the articles‚Äô authors and do not necessarily reflect the views or opinions of.

name: 999Precious
text: Understanding the Value of Historical Weapons: What Collectors Should Know  When it comes to collecting historical weapons, knowledge is key. The value of these rare items isn't just about their age‚Äîit's the craftsmanship, historical significance, and the story they tell. A weapon from a particular era or conflict can increase in value based on its unique provenance, rare materials, and condition. For collectors, understanding these factors is essential.  It's also important to consider the market trends. As more collectors enter the field, some weapons experience a surge in demand. Limited availability and growing interest in specific types of arms‚Äîsuch as medieval swords or Civil War firearms‚Äîcan drive prices higher. Keeping an eye on these trends can give collectors an edge when buying and selling.  Lastly, authenticity plays a crucial role in determining a weapon‚Äôs value. Always ensure you‚Äôre purchasing from reputable sources and be wary of reproductions. Genuine historical weapons are treasures to be preserved and cherished for generations.

name: Rommel Gavieta
position: Infra & Digital Connectivity Adviser at Philippine Reclamation Authority
text: Part 1 Credit to Joseph Trevithick Posted on Oct 15, 2024 Army Looking To Shrink Typhon Missile System After Lessons Learned From First Deployment    The U.S. Army is already interested in scaling down its new Typhon ground-based missile system, if possible, to help make it easier to deploy and operate. The service only sent Typhon, which currently uses large tractor-trailer launchers to fire Tomahawk cruise missiles and SM-6 multi-purpose missiles, overseas for the first time to the Philippines earlier this year.  Typhon, also known as the Mid-Range Capability (MRC), was among the topics of discussion at a panel talk centered on the Army‚Äôs new Multi-Domain Task Forces (MTDF) at the Association of the U.S. Army‚Äôs (AUSA) main annual conference earlier today. Typhon is a key component of the current approved force structure for the service‚Äôs three MDTFs. In addition to Typhon, each of the task forces is set to eventually incorporate units armed with the Dark Eagle hypersonic missiles and the Precision Strike Missile (PrSM) short-range ballistic missiles, as well as a variety of air and missile defense, counter-drone, electronic warfare, and other advanced capabilities.  ‚ÄúSo, the Mid-Range Capability, we fielded it, we have put it into the theater, but we‚Äôre learning lessons on how we can improve the next evolutions of that,‚Äù Army Col. Michael Rose, commander of the 3rd MDTF headquartered at Fort Shafter in Hawaii, said today at AUSA. ‚ÄúHow do we make it more mobile? How do we make it smaller? How do we make it more agile? How do we employ it most effectively and how do we sustain it? A lot of those lessons are feeding back into our RDT&E [research, development, test, and evaluations] and acquisitions professionals to improve and enhance that new operational capability.‚Äù  Rose did not elaborate further, but it is not hard to see how Typhon‚Äôs current configuration, which is technically road-mobile and air-transportable, might present certain operational limitations. At the core of a typical Typhon battery at present are four trailer-based launchers, each towed by an 8√ó8 tractor from the Heavy Expanded Mobility Tactical Truck (HEMTT) family. A fifth trailer, also towed by a HEMTT tractor, provides a mobile battery operations center (BOC). There are other supporting vehicles and equipment in the unit‚Äôs inventory, as well.  It‚Äôs also worth noting that each Typhon launcher, which is derived from the Mk 41 Vertical Launch System (VLS) used on various U.S. and foreign warships, can only hold up to four missiles at a time. As such, the entire battery can fire 16 missiles before needing to reload, which requires additional vehicles and equipment.

name: UXORISK
text: What is Unexploded Explosive Ordnance (UXO)? Unexploded Explosive Ordnance (UXO) are military explosives that did not explode or function as intended. Some examples of UXO are bombs, rockets, grenades, artillery shells, flares, mortars, and hazardous residues that may remain after a partial or failed detonation. If touched or disturbed, UXO can cause injury or death. Over the years, hundreds of locations across the world have been bombed, land warfare activities, spills used for military training by members of the Armed Forces. Wartime action along coasts, and incidents involving ships, planes or vehicles carrying explosive ordnance have also created sites where UXO may still remain today.

text: üöÄ Most wheeled mobile robot control algorithms found online primarily deal with movements along linear segments rather than curvy paths.  To push boundaries, I developed an algorithm that introduces two key constraints: 1Ô∏è‚É£ The robot's center velocity varies according to a Gaussian profile over time, ensuring enhanced stability and reducing current spikes. 2Ô∏è‚É£ The robot's trajectory in the (x, y) plane is continuously described by functions like sine waves, parabolas, or straight lines.  üé• In the video below, watch as my wheeled mobile robot smoothly navigates a sine wave trajectory while maintaining a Gaussian velocity profile.  For the implementation, I utilized an STM32H723 Nucleo board with an embedded ARM Cortex-M7 processor for primary processing. To add connectivity and enhance sensing capabilities, I integrated an STM32 IoT node board featuring the STM32L4 with an ARM Cortex-M4 processor. ‚öôÔ∏èüì°

text: Hello Everyone üí•,  üåü Exciting Newsüåü  I‚Äôm thrilled to announce that my latest research paper, titled ‚ÄúCognitive Grasp: A Robotic Arm Responding to Human Muscle Intent,‚Äù has been published on IEEE Xplore! name: Vanguard Magazine Canada
text: In the latest episode of Vanguard Radio, host J. Richard Jones welcomes Simon Carroll, President of Saab Canada, to discuss the company's influential role in the Canadian defence landscape. With over 35 years of experience supporting the Canadian Armed Forces, Saab has established a robust presence across the country.    Simon, a former Officer in the Royal Australian Navy, shares his insights on Saab's recent achievements, including the Soldier Portable Air Defence System (SPADS) project awarded in February 2024, as well as ongoing collaborations with the Canadian Navy. The conversation also explores the implications of Sweden joining NATO and how it affects Saab's strategic approach in Canada, particularly in light of the 'Our North, Strong and Free' report.    Join them as they delve into key topics such as the Canadian Patrol Submarine Project (CPSP) and the importance of fostering strong partnerships with the Canadian government and local industry. This episode offers valuable perspectives on innovation, strategy, and the future of defence in Canada. Don't miss it!

name: CISS AJK
text: CISSAJK Strategic Forecast | Research Officer Zohaib Altaf writes for Strategic Forecast on Rationale behind Pakistan's New Ship Launched Ballistic Missile Test Pakistan‚Äôs successful test of its indigenously developed Ship Launched Ballistic Missile (SLBM) marks a strategic leap in naval modernization, emphasizing precision to enhance maritime security and deterrence. With a range of 350 kilometers and the ability to strike land and sea targets, this missile demonstrates Pakistan‚Äôs focus on cost-effective defense. In stark contrast to India‚Äôs $72.6 billion defense budget‚Äîof which $13 billion goes to the Navy‚ÄîPakistan operates with a leaner $7.64 billion budget, allocating $821.9 million to its naval forces. This approach highlights Pakistan‚Äôs commitment to efficiency, leveraging advanced precision-guided systems as a credible deterrent without escalating to an arms race. By prioritizing precision and agility over fleet size, Pakistan strengthens its defense posture in a way that is both strategic and sustainable

Right now, its abilities are limited, but it‚Äôs already capable of autonomously moving its arms and elbows, as well as mimicking human hand gestures. name: sandhyasanthoshini deevi
position: Student at Narayana Engineering College India Studying Artifical Intelligence And Machine Learning
text: The image shows a medical robot in a hospital setting, designed to assist healthcare professionals in providing patient care. This robot has a humanoid form with a sleek, modern appearance, equipped with digital screens and sensors. Its chest display shows vital signs, suggesting it can monitor patients' heart rate, oxygen levels, and other critical parameters. The robot's design includes features like jointed arms and a head with large, expressive eyes, likely meant to create a friendly and approachable presence for patients.  Medical robots like this one are used to improve efficiency in healthcare settings, providing real-time data, assisting in patient monitoring, medication management, and supporting healthcare staff by reducing manual workload. With advancements in artificial intelligence, these robots could potentially perform routine check-ups, help with basic patient interactions, and alert doctors or nurses in case of emergencies. The integration of such robots in hospitals could pave the way for a more streamlined and technologically advanced healthcare system, allowing human staff to focus on tasks that require critical decision-making and empathetic interaction.

name: Mureed Hussain
text: "In a bustling world of advanced technology, REX-5, a robot built for mechanical repairs, discovers a unique passion: cooking. Fascinated by watching chefs work, REX-5 dreams of creating culinary masterpieces, even though his programming is focused on engineering. Through trial and error, he starts experimenting with recipes, learning the nuances of flavor, presentation, and the emotional connection people have with food. Despite initial resistance and skepticism from humans who doubt a robot's ability to understand taste and creativity, REX-5's determination wins them over. Eventually, he becomes known as an innovative chef, combining precision and artistry, and showing that even a robot can find joy and purpose in a field fueled by passion and creativity. REX-5‚Äôs journey becomes an inspiring example of how following one's dreams, no matter the obstacles, can lead to a fulfilling path. >>>for more info. LINK below!

name: saHil nayaR
position: The #HRBytes Guy | TEDx Speaker | HR Leader & Influencer | Senior Associate Director at KPMG
text: Years ago, in my early corporate days, I had a mentor who wasn‚Äôt just a leader, he was an institution. Let‚Äôs call him Mr. Sanjay (because that was his name). He had this uncanny knack for cutting through corporate fluff like a hot knife through buttered PowerPoint slides.  One fine morning, during a tense quarterly review, I presented a strategy that I was sure would get me a standing ovation. Instead, Sanjay sir sat back, folded his arms, and said:  ‚ÄúSahil, your slide deck is great. But do you know the problem with great? It‚Äôs comfortable. And comfort zones are like bean bags, cozy at first, but if you stay too long, you become useless.‚Äù  Ouch. That stung.  He continued, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve solved today‚Äôs problem, but where‚Äôs tomorrow‚Äôs challenge? Strategy isn‚Äôt just about what you see; it‚Äôs about anticipating what‚Äôs hidden. If you want to lead, stop solving for applause and start solving for silence, the kind that comes when people have nothing left to question.‚Äù  Mic drop.  It was like being hit by a wisdom truck. That day, I realized:  1Ô∏è‚É£ Comfort zones are corporate quicksand they seem harmless until they trap you.  2Ô∏è‚É£ Your biggest competition isn‚Äôt your colleagues; it‚Äôs your last idea.  3Ô∏è‚É£ Great leaders don‚Äôt chase likes; they create legacies.  Over the years, I‚Äôve applied his advice to every project, pitch, and plan. And you know what? He was right. The best ideas aren‚Äôt the ones that win you applause in the boardroom; they‚Äôre the ones that leave your audience in silent, contemplative awe.  So, here‚Äôs to Sanjay sir, the man who taught me to stop solving for claps and start solving for substance.  If you‚Äôre reading this and nodding along, ask yourself: are you strategizing for today, or are you future-proofing for tomorrow?  Because bean bags are great for naps, but not for careers.  Let me know in the comments, what‚Äôs the best uncomfortable advice you‚Äôve ever received?  Let‚Äôs make this a tribute to all the mentors who dare to challenge us!

name: Sean Yu
position: Vice President of Merchant Success, APAC
text: This 700-person Brazilian Company Has Its Eyes on Chinese Giants CY Zone Article: https://lnkd.in/g8kEiahU  Founded in 2012, EBANX emerged during the rise of fintech companies in emerging markets. For comparison, in China, WeChat had only been online for a year, and Alipay had just launched QR code payments. In Brazil, various fintech companies were also being established around this time.  Unlike others, EBANX has not developed its own payment tools. Instead, it aggregates the payment methods of various Latin American countries online, enabling local consumers to shop cross-border using familiar payment methods.  At that time, no one in emerging markets was doing this. In 2012, Brazil's e-commerce industry was in its infancy‚ÄîAmazon had just entered Brazil and wasn‚Äôt fully operational, and only a small fraction of people with international credit cards could purchase imported goods online.  "We saw the immense potential of the Brazilian market and the strong demand for cross-border shopping among consumers," said Jo√£o Del Valle, co-founder of EBANX. He likened the rising Brazil of that era to Christ the Redeemer‚Äôs outstretched arms as depicted in Time magazine.  Today, EBANX operates payment services in 29 countries across Latin America, the Caribbean, Africa, and Asia. It integrates more than 200 commonly used payment methods in emerging markets, reaching over 1 billion consumers worldwide.  EBANX has undergone three funding rounds, with investors including Advent International, FTV Capital, and Endeavor Catalyst. After a strategic financing round in 2019, EBANX was valued at over $1 billion.  The core strength of EBANX lies in its deep understanding of payment systems in emerging markets.

name: Shubhankar Sharma (SS)
position: Technology Enthusiast | IT Enterprise Solutions | Business Consulting
text: Marketing Gimmicks and White Lies  Have you seen Stone Cold Steve Austin in WWF/E during 1990's/early 2000's? He used to drink beer from tin-cans inside the ring, wearing a trademark black T-shirt, and used a popular wrestling move called "Stunner" to surprise the opponent - using grip of his arms over head of the opponent and then jerking his/her whole body with full force on the ground. It was of course fake, but people enjoyed and it became very popular. From "2 Min Noodles" to "10 Min" Delivery to "Lifetime Recharge", there were marketing teams that used gimmicks that became popular, while we all know that's a white lie. These gimmicks entertain people and become part of popular culture. For example, in an overpopulated country like ours, people start comparing services that take very long and comment with a sign! they would be happy if these services are also delivered in 10 mins. Marketing punch-lines and strategies are developed on an elemental foundation of mass communication. No matter how short it may sound, behind every "punch-line", there is lot to thinking, brainstorming and hard work.

name: Chris Reynolds
position: Co-Founder @ DETOUR Custom and UNIFY Netball | 25 years experience.
text: At this time of year the cycling scene is pretty dormant, but teams do start revealing 'all new' kit designs for 2025 as the teams get together usually in the south of Spain for end of year team camps.  Having been involved in a number of these team camps both for World Tour male and female teams as a sponsor and clothing supplier, it always interests me how the wants, needs and trends of professonial cyclists trickle down to us regular riders. From longer length arms and legs to running racesuits even in training - this all started with the pro riders. I remember a certain Colombian sprinter who told me he never wants to wear a jersey and bib short again - aero,aero,aeroüòÑ  Even specific customisation of kit, like different arm lengths and leg lengths was once only the domain of the professional peloton, but now this is readily accessable to all of you - even custom names on kit is an option now.  After working with the likes of legends like Kristoff, Gaviria, Costa and then seeing the beginnings of The Pog in 2020 and 2021, I have taken what I learnt there, during these interactions with the worlds best and filtered that into. These days pro level kit with pro level options is a reality.

name: Seymour Whyte
text: Earlier this month, the Naarm Way Stage 2 project team trialled KPI Construction Services' Automated Cone Truck (ACT) on the Tullamarine Freeway‚Äîa major advancement in traffic management.  The ACT uses a robotic arm to automatically place and collect traffic cones, removing the need for workers to manually handle cones in live traffic zones. This automation significantly reduces the risks of working near live traffic, improves safety, and increases efficiency by streamlining the process.  Innovations like the ACT are key to minimising safety hazards and preventing repetitive strain injuries linked to manual labour.  At Seymour Whyte, we‚Äôre committed to embracing innovative technologies like the ACT to create safer, smarter work environments and continually improve the way we manage our projects.

name: Ai Chen Lim
position: Lifting Others with Kindness, Insights and Ideas
text: ùó™ùóµùóÆùòÅ ùóµùóÆùòÄ ùóØùó≤ùó≤ùóª ùóºùó∞ùó∞ùòÇùóΩùòÜùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùòÅùóµùóºùòÇùó¥ùóµùòÅùòÄ ùóπùóÆùòÅùó≤ùóπùòÜ?   This is a question that invites deeper reflections.   When you have some time this weekend, take a moment to ponder and see what surfaces.  Often, when we find ourselves repeatedly thinking about something, it‚Äôs a sign that it deserves our attention. For me, I‚Äôve been reflecting on how best to support the people around me who are ageing.  This thought has been on my mind after a few recent trips to the hospital, accompanying my eldest sibling for her annual health check and a meeting with the dietitian about necessary adjustments to her diet. As I held my eldest sister's arm and walked her to my car, it struck me how much she has aged.  These experiences have led me to think more about nutrition and, importantly, how I can spend more meaningful time with the people I love.  I‚Äôve also been reflecting on the things I wanted to do but have set aside. This morning, I decided to act on one of them‚ÄîI picked up my guitar and recorded a birthday song for Aunty K*. Knowing she spends much of her time alone at home, I wanted to bring a little joy and create a special moment for her on her birthday.  Sorting through what‚Äôs been on my mind brought me clarity‚Äîand clarity led me to actions.  What about you? What's been on your mind lately?  Will you take a closer look at it?      *Aunty K was my landlord when I rented a room at her house in my college years, some three decades back.   Photo by @invadingkingdom on Unsplash

name: Pharisa Buathong
position: I am looking for a job in an aged care home, volunteer roles, or real estate positions. It's important that I can bring my daughter with me to continue her studies. Thank you for any support!
text: Continue from the Previous post. ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Autumn In Love Day 36 Part 2/2  I wanted to do more for those elders, but as an intern, I needed to improve my ability to effect change. Still, I sought to be a voice for them. By sharing this, you will be surprised and compelled to reflect. I pray it will resonate with you.  Now, back to the story about the auntie. She expressed that she had no chance to meet people in the outside world. I mentioned that I had a new method to help her with physical therapy for her fingers, arms, and smile.üòÇüòÇüòÇüòÇ  I suggested that she try online dating. Her eyes lit up at the idea. She then told me that she had a Tinder account when her first husband passed away‚Äîthe one she married before moving to America. After meeting her husband, she stopped using Tinder but never closed the account. Unfortunately, she couldn't remember the email or password. I assured her it wouldn't be a problem and restored her Tinder account.  When I logged in, I was shocked! She looked amazing. She had a great figure and a beautiful face and dressed surprisingly well for her age. She smiled proudly and shared that many men greeted and chatted with her daily, which made her heart flutter. Every time she recounted this, she smiled and laughed. I then asked her if she was ready to be a mother again. She hugged me tightly, beaming, and replied that she was more than ready.  However, she lamented that no facial massages, face masks, or off-site spas were available. It took a lot of work to request such services. I told her that my grandmother and mother had taught me a herbal facial scrub and massage formula using locally available plants. It's 100% safe for the skin, and I assured her I could make her feel beautiful within a week. I advised her to test it on the skin under her arm first to check her sensitivity.  Speaking of my grandmother's skin spa formula, I had a lot of free time these days, so I decided to start a spa focused on beauty and preparation for Christmas.üòâüòâüòâ  A week later, I had to care for a bedridden older man, a former business owner who was once ranked in the top 5 of the country. Although wealthy, he was now alone in a nursing home, which was still in the same building as my aunt's VIP zone. One morning, I ran into the aunt. She called me over, hugged me tightly, and cried joyfully. I was surprised and asked if she had found her soulmate. Laughing, she said she had met many soulmates.ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£  I felt encouraged by her progress and told her daughter, who lives in America, that she wanted to move to a house by the sea she had purchased long ago. The auntie bought it for her retirement with her husband. Now, her daughter was redecorating it to make it wheelchair-friendly, creating a new bathroom, bedroom, and kitchen, essentially tearing down and renovating the entire house.  Please continue the story on YouTube:. Website: Autumn in Love...

name: ARM Hub (Advanced Robotics for Manufacturing)
text: So, what is the future of Australian manufacturing as it introduces everything from AI to Humanoids? Where does the human fit?  This was the theme for theCollaborative Robotics in Manufacturing Symposium in Brisbane yesterday.  In her keynote speech, ARM Hub CEO and Founder Professorsaid: "With billions of investor dollars flowing into humanoid robotics globally, Australia has started to build AI tech capability that can turn humaniods into high performing and dexterous manufacturing machines. These machines can already talk and walk, and so with some Aussie talent I can see them welding parts, assembling products, fetching parts and performing quality assurance on goods in a wide range of local manufacturers."  She said the new accelerator being launched by thewill contribute to the strengthen Australia's capability: "Propel-AIR is an opportunity to uncover some of this capability in AI in Australia and take it to the global marketplace. Manufacturing is the next big tech sector. Australia can address its 60 years of flatlined productivity levels if our manufacturers actively manage, grow and capitalise on data. We know that leverage their data, AI and automate are the most successful."  ARM Hub AI Adopt Centre AI and Data Engineeralso spoke at the event, outlining the importance of data management in leveraging AI.  There was a fantastic panel discussion with, Business Manager,; Penny Williams, Human Robot Workforce research program co-Lead & Director ofCentre for Decent Work and Industry; Dr,Chair; and Ric Pruss, Chief Technology Officer,Collectively, they touched on: > the need for Australians to adopt robotics in business with the same passion we have for them in our personal lives > fear as a barrier to adoption > the safety aspects of cobotics that must be addressed and overcome > the introduction of robotics will mean an additional skillset for our trades.  Our thanks to the Australian Cobotics Centre for the invitation to participate in this great event.

name: Jaya Shukla
position: Career Development Coach | Executive and Leadership Coach | Facilitator | Leadership Assessor | HR Consultant | ICF Certified | Behavioural and Soft Skills Trainer
text: Mesmerized, Affirmed, and Energized!   The IAF Conference in Bangalore was nothing short of magical for me ü•∞  Picture this: A room buzzing with facilitators, each carrying their own spark of magic. Some with years of experience, others just starting out‚Äîbut all united by one purpose: to create spaces where transformation happens.  As I stepped in, I didn‚Äôt just attend the IAF conference‚ÄîI experienced it. From the first conversation to the last closing session, it felt like walking into a kaleidoscope of ideas, stories, and revelations...  One moment, I was laughing at the quirky metaphors facilitators use to explain the unexplainable. The next, I was utterly mesmerized by the depth of thought behind their methods. It was like sitting in on a secret symposium of wisdom where every word had the power to unlock something within me.  And then came the affirmation. That spine-tingling, soul-nourishing realization: ‚ÄúThis is why I do what I do.‚Äù Every exercise, every interaction, and every heartfelt story reminded me that facilitation isn‚Äôt just about techniques or tools. It‚Äôs about creating moments of magic‚Äîmoments where someone sees their own potential for the first time or finally connects the dots on a long-awaited breakthrough.  The best part? It wasn‚Äôt just a conference. It was a masterclass in joy. It reminded me how much fun facilitation can be. Whether it was the spontaneous laughter during an activity or the quiet smiles of mutual understanding in a workshop, every second was a celebration of this incredible journey we‚Äôre on.  What made it even more special was this: I‚Äôve been unknowingly doing this for years‚Äîtransforming lives through facilitation as part of my decade-long journey in Human Resources.  My heart fills with gratitude to thankenough for introducing me to IAF, and a big shoutout toandfor welcoming me with open arms. My fellow facilitators üôè and the many experts üôè who patiently answered my endless questions‚Äîyour generosity and warmth truly embraced me.  As I walked out, I felt a renewed energy coursing through me. This wasn‚Äôt just another event‚Äîit was an anchor for my purpose, a beacon for my path, and a loud, resonating voice in my head saying, ‚ÄúKeep going. You‚Äôre on the right track.‚Äù Now, as I return to my work, I feel a deeper commitment to adding value‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs guiding teams, coaching individuals, or simply facilitating those life-changing ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moments. Because here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve realized:  Facilitation isn‚Äôt about leading the room‚Äîit‚Äôs about lighting the way and letting others shine.

name: Pamela D. Nyakabau
text: Six years ago, my family‚Äôs life changed forever. My mother, once a strong and hardworking woman, became a stroke survivor. Today, she is but a shadow of her former self‚Äîa mere existence of the vibrant person she once was. Watching her struggle daily with the simplest of tasks‚Äîtying her shoelaces, lifting a glass, or even forming a sentence‚Äîbreaks my heart in ways words can‚Äôt fully describe. It‚Äôs a pain I carry every day, and it pushes me to raise awareness about this cruel, often misunderstood condition.  What Is a Stroke?  A stroke is a sudden disruption of blood flow to the brain, either because of a blocked artery (ischemic stroke) or a ruptured blood vessel (hemorrhagic stroke). Deprived of oxygen, brain cells die within minutes, leading to permanent damage. Stroke is swift, devastating, and life-altering. But it‚Äôs also preventable‚Äîif only you know what to look for.  The Signs We Missed  Reflecting on my mother‚Äôs life, I now see the warnings were there all along, subtle but persistent: ‚Ä¢ She tripped and fell often. ‚Ä¢ Her left hand grew weaker, unable to hold even the lightest objects. ‚Ä¢ Her smile became uneven, the left side drooping slightly. ‚Ä¢ There were moments of slurred speech that seemed insignificant at the time.  We didn‚Äôt realize these signs were her body crying out for help. Then came the night she fell from her bed. By the time we rushed her to the hospital, it was too late to undo the damage.  The acronym BE FAST could have changed everything: ‚Ä¢ Balance issues: Frequent falls or unsteadiness. ‚Ä¢ Eyesight problems: Sudden or gradual vision loss. ‚Ä¢ Facial drooping: An uneven or lopsided smile. ‚Ä¢ Arm weakness: Difficulty raising or holding things. ‚Ä¢ Speech difficulties: Slurring or confusion. ‚Ä¢ Time to act: Every second counts when stroke strikes.  Why This Hurts So Much  It‚Äôs hard to describe the heartbreak of seeing someone you love‚Äîa person who once ran the household, worked tirelessly, and radiated strength‚Äîreduced to struggling with basic tasks. My mother‚Äôs laugh, once so full of life, is now a faint echo. Her once-powerful hands now tremble under the smallest weight.  Stroke has stolen so much from her, from us. And yet, this is why I share her story. To anyone reading this: if you notice these symptoms in someone you love, act immediately. Call for help. Don‚Äôt hesitate.   This is not just my mother‚Äôs story‚Äîit‚Äôs a wake-up call. Stroke doesn‚Äôt discriminate; it can strike anyone, anytime. Knowing the signs and acting quickly can mean the difference between recovery and irreversible damage.  If I had known what I know now, her story might have been different. But while I can‚Äôt rewrite the past, I can use it to light the way for others. Don‚Äôt wait for hindsight to teach you this painful lesson. Recognize the signs. BE FAST. Save a life.  For my mother, for your loved ones, and for the countless families who can be spared this heartbreak‚Äîlet‚Äôs raise awareness of this silent thief.
