name: Charlie Koster
text: "Show me metrics of how much of the monolith codebase has been migrated to our new design system. Break it down by layouts, forms, and other components."  Requests like these are not uncommon in tech organizations, but they are not straightforward. With unclear acceptance criteria, likely scope creep, and technical challenges these types of requests are not fun to work in a traditional software development model. Should they even be prioritized? And if so, how do you estimate them?  This week I teamed up with another Architect to tackle this exact request. I acted as the Developer utilizing OpenAI‚Äôs o1 model, while my partner took on the role of Product Manager. Through iterative experimentation we clarified requirements and refined partial solutions over several days‚Äîworking in 30-minute bursts between our meeting-packed calendars.  By keeping principles in mind, I utilized o1 to produce incremental scripted reports and continuously refined the output with feedback. In under 25 interactions with o1, we delivered a solution that provided actionable metrics on migration progress‚Äîbroken down by component type.  This request was the perfect size and shape for today‚Äôs state-of-the-art LLMs, a statement I expect not to age well as the AI arms race continues to yield near exponential improvements.  Looking ahead, 2025 will be the year organizations need to not only keep up with AI advancements but also learn how to seamlessly integrate LLMs into their workflows.

name: Pearlyn K.

text: This week, my son graduated from K2, and my heart is full. It feels like just yesterday he was a tiny baby in my arms. How does time fly so quickly? Kid: Twirls on the salon chair like a pop star on tour üé§.  Life as a remote-working mum? It‚Äôs juggling deadlines, impromptu hair appointments, and kiddo performances all in one. text: Hey connections,   SolidWorks : BOBCAT 3D Model üöú  I'm excited to showcase one of my recent 3D modeling projects in SolidWorks ‚Äì a BOBCAT, designed with precision and creativity. This project involved creating 21 unique parts, assembling them seamlessly, and ensuring every detail aligned with the functional aspects of the machine.  Key Features of My Design:  ‚úÖ Parts List:  1. Main Body 2. Bucket 3. Cabin 4. Back Cover with Bulb 5. Cabin Cup & Pin 6. Front Light Bulb, Case 7. Bulb Cover 8. Front Light Glass 9. Cylinder Rod & Body 10. Lifting Arm 11. Exhaust Pipe 12. Arm Pin 13. Axle 14. Rim 15. Tire   üìå Skills Applied:  Advanced parametric modeling for individual components.  Precise assembly and motion analysis to ensure functionality.  Attention to aesthetic detailing while maintaining structural accuracy.   This project was not only a technical challenge but also a highly rewarding experience. It took time and effort, but every step was engaging and educational.  üí° Why this matters:  This BOBCAT model reflects my ability to handle complex designs and deliver results suitable for real-world applications. It also demonstrates my proficiency in SolidWorks, a skill I'm eager to contribute to future design challenges.  I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts and feedback on this project. name: Aries Saputra
text: Food and beverage maker PepsiCo Indonesia will begin producing snacks at its new factory in Cikarang, West Java, in the first quarter of 2025. The local arm of United States-based PepsiCo had committed itself to building the snack factory back in 2023, with investment estimated at US$200 million over a 10-year period. The site will manufacture the company‚Äôs flagship snacks, including Lays, Cheetos and Doritos for the domestic market, with plans for gradual exports to other ASEAN countries. ‚ÄúWe hope to start operations early next year to produce Lays, Cheetos and Doritos,‚Äù said Gabrielle Angriani Johny, director of government affairs and corporate communications at PepsiCo Indonesia Read more:

name: Steven-Paul Walker MBA, CISA, CGEIT, CICA
position: Risk and Regulatory Compliance Practice Expert | Certified Information Systems Auditor
text: An interesting article on potentially a whole new world of doing business. The risks associated with streamlining or eliminating the regulatory oversight mechanism role can be fraught with red flags. Eliminating a cabinet level agency or the supervisory arm of the FDIC and though it's not mentioned, the supervisory arm the Federal Reserve (regulator of bank holding companies) would require a great deal of congressional scrutiny and I suspect at the end of day, would find bi-partisan support for taking cautionary steps in this direction. It's been my professional experience that when regulatory contact is performed with common sense, adherence to law and in accordance with best business practices, senior bank managers and board directors find the discussions positive and very helpful to their enterprise risk management processes and control activities. I would even argue institutions with a strong culture of controls encouraged by internal audit and excellent regulation retain strong franchise value. Stay tuned regarding changes like what's being contemplated by the in-coming administration as outlined in this article. If this path is followed a significant level of safeguards could be removed from the financial services industry which will no doubt permeate public perception. Institutions of all asset sizes and profiles of complexity are already challenged with existing safety and soundness rules in areas such as risk-based capital planning, credit risk, net interest margin maintenance, liquidity and funds management. Financial institutions are now facing an array of emerging technology and operational risk introduced by cryptocurrency, blockchain and AI; these technologies are promising to influence their business model in ways they may not be totally ready to implement or factor into their enterprise risk management programs. Effective, independent and efficient supervisory regulation can be very helpful in helping bank managers navigate and focus their efforts when addressing these risks. Further, it can ensure the ground rules for competition remain even and consistent among market participants as managers navigate these challenges going forward.

text: For late Friday the 13th is this commentary by Debra Saunders, Washington columnist for the Las Vegas Review-Journal distributed by Creators.com. Entitled : Joe Biden‚Äôs Work-From-Home Bureaucracy. As orders of Bengay pour into the WH for Joey's sore arm from rubber stamping all of those pardons set in front of him, is this commentary. Order more stamps, more ink, more paper. Hmm...so how long has the covid mess been over.....Or better yet ask how many in real business have returned to their offices. If these people remain at home, then why do we pay for all of this space? Let alone, how well are they doing their jobs. Any duplication of services. Yep in mergers and "splurgers" in the real world of business duplication means someone is going to go...thus layoff. Yes perhaps that Argentine president has a thoughtful, common sense plan to get rid of the bloat. This morning per various articles that in Argentina the current president has put this country in the black for the first time in 123 years. Change coming ....on to it...  ...."March 2020. The headquarters of most agencies remain largely abandoned,‚Äù Sen. Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, wrote in a report released Thursday that paints a dystopian picture of the federal workforce inside the vaunted beltway. It‚Äôs been nearly five years since COVID-19 knocked on America‚Äôs door. Most schools and businesses opened up years ago. But federal government operations in Washington, D.C., are behind the flyover states. Because of COVID-19, President Joe Biden campaigned from home in 2020. But after American classrooms and businesses reopened, Biden has been a frequently absent executive since he took the oath of office. Ernst figured Biden ‚Äúwas out of office 532 days over the last three-and-a-half years, about 40% of the time he was expected to be in the Oval Office.‚Äù.... text: üåä Powering the Future of LNG Transfer üö¢  As the LNG industry continues to expand, the demand for safe, efficient, and reliable transfer systems has never been greater. name: Debbie Everett, ARM
position: Property Manager IREM Board Member 2025 Las Vegas Chapter NV. RE #S.0172157 PM #168548
text: We held the last ARM Breakfast of the year with such an amazing presentation with our two guest speakers Teresa Jackson and JoAnne Williams with JWilliams Staffing.  We talked all things staffing, recruiting and retaining. Our speakers had relevant material on the subject of the future in multifamily and the job market in general in Las Vegas headed into 2025. I couldn't be more grateful to all who attended and came out to support.

name: Institute for the Study of War
text: NEW: Russian forces conducted their largest series of missile and drone strikes against Ukraine since the start of the war overnight on December 12 to 13, largely targeting Ukrainian energy infrastructure.  Read more in the December 13, 2024 Russian Offensive Campaign Assessment:  Russia's strike series targeting Ukrainian energy facilities is part of a broader campaign aimed at freezing out Ukraine in Winter 2024-2025 and compelling Ukraine and the West to self-deter into making policy decisions that benefit Russia.  Ukrainian strikes against military airfields in Russia and Russian air defense systems in near rear areas may be prompting a decrease in Russian air operations and glide bomb strikes against Ukraine.  Russia is evacuating elements of its force grouping in Syria while continuing negotiations with select Syrian groups about Russia's longer-term military presence in the country.  The status of Russia's helicopter base at Qamishli in northeastern Syria remains unclear, however.  The US Department of Defense (DoD) announced on December 12 a new military aid package for Ukraine valued at $500 million.  A Russian insider source who has previously correctly predicted command changes within the Russian military responded to recent claims that the Russian military command removed 3rd Combined Arms Army (formerly 2nd Luhansk People's Republic Army Corps) commander Major General Dmitry Ovcharov.  Russian forces recently advanced near Pokrovsk and Vuhledar.  Russian President Vladimir Putin awarded Rosgvardia Head Viktor Zolotov with the Hero of Russia award.
